formulas.name: Planned Value (PV)
formulas.description: Budget for scheduled work (What you PLANNED to spend)

formulas.name: Earned Value (EV)
formulas.description: Budget for completed work (Value of work DONE)

formulas.name: Actual Cost (AC)
formulas.description: Actual cost incurred (What you ACTUALLY spent)

formulas.name: Budget at Completion (BAC)
formulas.description: Total project budget

formulas.name: Cost Variance (CV)
formulas.description: Difference between earned value and actual cost

formulas.name: Schedule Variance (SV)
formulas.description: Difference between earned value and planned value

example.interpretation: Project is $5,000 worth of work behind schedule

formulas.name: Cost Performance Index (CPI)
formulas.description: Cost efficiency of work performed

interpretation.greater_than_1: Under budget (Good) - earning more than spending
interpretation.less_than_1: Over budget (Bad) - spending more than earning

example.interpretation: For every dollar spent, only $0.91 of value is earned - project is over budget

commonMistakes: Using AC / EV instead of EV / AC

formulas.name: Schedule Performance Index (SPI)
formulas.description: Schedule efficiency of work performed

example.interpretation: Project is progressing at 88% of planned rate

formulas.name: Estimate at Completion (Typical)
formulas.description: Expected total cost if current cost performance continues
formulas.whenToUse: Most common; assumes current cost performance continues

example.interpretation: Project will finish over budget at $120,482

commonMistakes: Using wrong EAC formula for situation

formulas.name: Estimate at Completion (Atypical)
formulas.description: Expected total cost when current variance is one-time
formulas.whenToUse: Current variance is one-time, won't repeat

formulas.name: Estimate at Completion (CPI × SPI)
formulas.description: Expected total cost considering both cost and schedule
formulas.whenToUse: Both cost and schedule efficiency need to be considered

formulas.name: Estimate to Complete (ETC)
formulas.description: Expected cost to finish remaining work

example.interpretation: Need $78,482 more to complete the project

formulas.name: Variance at Completion (VAC)
formulas.description: Expected budget variance at project completion

formulas.name: To-Complete Performance Index (BAC)
formulas.description: Cost efficiency needed on remaining work to meet original budget

interpretation.less_than_1: Can afford to be less efficient (easier)

example.interpretation: Need 12% efficiency improvement to meet original budget

formulas.name: To-Complete Performance Index (EAC)
formulas.description: Cost efficiency needed on remaining work to meet revised estimate
formulas.whenToUse: When original BAC is no longer realistic and new EAC has been established

formulas.name: Early Start (ES)
formulas.formula: ES = Latest EF of all predecessors (or 0 for first activity)
formulas.description: Earliest an activity can start

formulas.name: Early Finish (EF)
formulas.description: Earliest an activity can finish

formulas.name: Late Finish (LF)
formulas.formula: LF = Earliest LS of all successors (or project EF for last activity)
formulas.description: Latest an activity can finish without delaying project

formulas.name: Late Start (LS)
formulas.description: Latest an activity can start without delaying project

formulas.name: Total Float
formulas.formula: Total Float = LS - ES (or LF - EF)
formulas.description: Time an activity can be delayed without delaying project completion
commonMistakes: Thinking critical path has most activities instead of zero float

formulas.name: Free Float
formulas.description: Time an activity can be delayed without delaying early start of successor

formulas.name: Critical Path
formulas.description: Longest sequence of activities; determines minimum project duration

formulas.name: PERT (Beta Distribution)
formulas.description: Three-point estimate giving more weight to most likely
formulas.whenToUse: Most common on exam; weights 'Most Likely' higher

example.given: O = 3 days, M = 5 days, P = 9 days

formulas.name: Triangular Distribution
formulas.description: Simple average of three estimates with equal weight
formulas.whenToUse: Simple average, equal weight to all estimates

formulas.name: Standard Deviation (σ)
formulas.description: Measure of uncertainty/variability in estimate

formulas.name: Variance
formulas.description: Square of standard deviation

formulas.name: Communication Channels
formulas.description: Number of communication channels in a group
formulas.keyInsight: Adding just one person significantly increases communication complexity

formulas.name: Return on Investment (ROI)
formulas.formula: [(Gain from Investment - Cost of Investment) / Cost of Investment] × 100%
formulas.description: Percentage return on investment

formulas.name: Benefit-Cost Ratio (BCR)
formulas.description: Ratio of benefits to costs

formulas.name: Payback Period
formulas.description: Time to recover investment cost

example.interpretation: Investment will be recovered in 4 years

formulas.selectionRule: Choose project with shortest payback period

formulas.name: Net Present Value (NPV)
formulas.formula: Present value of future cash flows - Initial investment
formulas.description: Value of project in today's dollars

formulas.name: Internal Rate of Return (IRR)
formulas.description: Rate of return that makes NPV zero

formulas.name: Velocity
formulas.formula: Total Story Points Completed in Sprint
formulas.description: Team's capacity to complete work in a sprint

example.given: Sprint 1: 25 pts, Sprint 2: 30 pts, Sprint 3: 28 pts
example.interpretation: Team can complete ~28 points per sprint

formulas.name: Number of Sprints
formulas.description: Calculate how many sprints needed

example.given: Product Backlog: 150 story points, Average Velocity: 25 pts/sprint

examTips: Write formulas FIRST - Brain dump at start of exam
Identify what's given - Circle known values
Identify what's asked - Underline the question
Show your work - Use scratch paper
Check if answer makes sense - CPI < 1 = over budget

evm: Confusing CV and SV (use correct formula!)
cpm: Adding instead of comparing in forward/backward pass
Thinking critical path has most activities (it's LONGEST, not most)
estimation: Using triangular when PERT is needed (exam usually wants PERT)
Confusing standard deviation with variance (variance = σ²)

brainDumpTemplate:
EVM FORMULAS:
CV = EV - AC          CPI = EV / AC
SV = EV - PV          SPI = EV / PV
EAC = BAC/CPI         ETC = EAC - AC
VAC = BAC - EAC       TCPI = (BAC-EV)/(BAC-AC)

CPM:
Total Float = LS - ES
Free Float = ES(next) - EF(current)
Critical Path = Zero Float

ESTIMATION:
PERT = (O + 4M + P) / 6
σ = (P - O) / 6
±1σ = 68%, ±2σ = 95%, ±3σ = 99.7%

COMMUNICATION:
Channels = n(n-1)/2

FINANCIAL:
ROI = (Gain - Cost) / Cost × 100%
BCR = Benefits / Costs
Higher NPV = Better
Higher IRR = Better
